folklore.name: Black Cat Crossing
folklore.story_full: A black cat crossing your path is the devil's familiar testing your resolve. Stop walking, turn around three times, and spit over your left shoulder, or the day's fortune turns against you. The cat sees into the spirit world, pulling bad luck behind it like a shadow. Sailors would rather delay a voyage than let a black cat cross their path.

folklore.name: Spilled Salt
folklore.story_full: Salt was once worth more than gold, and spilling it meant a fight was coming. The crystals scatter like words you can't take back, each grain a harsh word waiting to be spoken. Throw a pinch over your left shoulder to blind the devil watching there, hoping to stoke anger into violence. The stain reminds you that some mistakes invite conflict.

folklore.name: Whistling Indoors
folklore.story_full: Never whistle inside a Russian home, or you'll whistle away all your money. The sound calls to wind spirits who blow your prosperity out the windows and carry it to the four corners of the earth. Grandmothers still scold children who forget, remembering when a single whistled note cost their family the harvest money. It's a warning written in generations of empty pockets.

folklore.name: Broken Mirror
folklore.story_full: A mirror is a doorway to the soul, and breaking one shatters your fate into pieces. Seven years of misfortune for each broken glass, as your reflection was part of you that's now scattered and sharp. The shards must be wrapped in black cloth and buried at a crossroads at midnight to bind the curse. Never look into a broken mirror.

folklore.name: Corner Seating
folklore.story_full: An unmarried person who sits at the corner of the table will wait seven years before they find a spouse. The corner is a place of division, splitting your romantic fortune in two. Young people are pulled away from corners at family gatherings, sometimes physically relocated. It's not just superstition when you've watched your cousin sit at the corner and remain single year after year.

folklore.name: Empty Vessels
folklore.story_full: Never place an empty bottle or bucket on the table, or you invite poverty to dine with you. Empty containers are hungry mouths waiting to be filled, and they'll devour your wealth if given the chance. Even in the poorest homes, bottles are placed on the floor, never the table. Fill what you can, hide what you cannot, but never let emptiness take a seat.

folklore.name: Returning Home
folklore.story_full: Once you've left your home, returning for something forgotten brings terrible luck. The threshold remembers your departure, and crossing it twice confuses your fate. If you must go back, look into a mirror before leaving again—it resets your journey. Soldiers especially fear this omen, knowing that a forgotten wallet might cost more than money. Better to manage without it.

folklore.name: Threshold Handshake
folklore.story_full: The threshold is neither inside nor outside—a boundary where spirits dwell. Never shake hands or pass objects across it, or discord follows. Step fully inside or outside first. Deals made across thresholds fail. Friendships fracture. The house spirits keep score, and the debt is paid in broken trust.

folklore.name: Bird at Window
folklore.story_full: When a bird taps at your window, death is sending a messenger. Birds fly between this world and the next, and when one tries to enter your home, a soul is preparing to leave. If the bird is black, death comes for an elder. If white, a child. If it returns three nights in a row, there's no preventing what's coming.

folklore.name: Itchy Left Palm
folklore.story_full: When your left hand itches, money is coming to you. Scratch the itch against wood to seal the fortune, against metal to multiply it, but never against stone or it turns to loss. Some people kiss their itching left palm three times, calling the coins closer. Whether it works or not, the itch makes you think about money, and thinking about it is the first step to finding it.

folklore.name: Itchy Right Palm
folklore.story_full: When your right hand itches, money will leave. The old ones say to scratch it against your pocket to keep the coins from escaping, or clench your fist tight and hold on. But sometimes money must flow out to flow back in. The right hand gives what the left hand receives, and both are necessary for fortune's wheel to turn.

folklore.name: Shoes on Table
folklore.story_full: Place shoes on a table, and you place death in the home. Shoes belong to the earth, to the outside world, to the realm of dirt and spirits. Elevating them to where you eat is an insult to the house and an invitation to the grave. The superstition comes from old times when the dead were measured for coffins on tables, their shoes placed beside them.

folklore.name: Gift Knives
folklore.story_full: A knife given as a gift cuts the relationship between giver and receiver. The sharp edge slices through friendship, family bonds, and love, leaving only coldness. To break the curse, the receiver must give a coin in return, even a kopek, transforming the gift into a purchase. Without payment, every knife carries the prophecy of its own nature—eventual cutting, eventual pain.

folklore.name: Meeting Empty Bucket
folklore.story_full: Meeting a person carrying an empty bucket means your day will be empty of success. The void they carry spreads to your endeavors, draining them of fortune. Turn around and wait, or spit three times to break the curse. Fishermen who see empty buckets return home immediately, knowing the nets will be bare. The empty seeks to fill itself with your luck.

folklore.name: Even Flowers for Graves
folklore.story_full: Give an even number of flowers only to the dead. Living people receive odd numbers—one, three, five, seven. Even numbers belong to graves and funerals, a tribute to those who've passed beyond. Hand someone an even bouquet, and you've wished them death. The rule is absolute, observed by everyone from street vendors to presidents. Count carefully, or insult deeply.
